title: How much time after MOS school in the Marines do I have before I report to my first duty station? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer is, “It varies”. Understand though that leave accrues at 2.5 days per month of active duty. While you get 30 days of leave per year, it’s not something granted the moment you arrive at boot camp. The math works out like this. 3 months of boot camp and your accrue 7.5 days of leave. Most Marines take leave between boot camp and their MOS training. If you take 2 weeks (14 days), which is normally acceptable, you go into a leave debt of 6.5 days. It’ll take another 3 months before your balance goes above zero. If your MOS training is 3 months, then you’ll only have 1 day of leave accrued when training is completed. You may be authorized to go on leave again, but you’ll go into leave debt again. If you take another 14 days, you’ll be negative 13 days by the time you reach your duty station. When you arrive at your permanent duty station, I can guarantee that they won’t let you accrue any more negative days (unless it’s an extreme emergency). So, you’ll have 6 months before you can take a day off again. Do yourself a favor and only take 7 days after boot camp, then another 7 after MOS training. You’ll thank yourself in the long run. Trust me. The girl ain’t worth it. Your old friends aren’t worth it. Your family may be worth but you’ll be sick of them after a week anyway. Get your training done, get to your permanent duty station, then use accrued leave to bring the important people to you so they can see the new life you have.

It depends on how much leave you have saved up. You accumulate 2.5 days per month. If you take leave after boot camp like, most Marines, that’s usually a week or so. Then it’s on to MCT or SOI. That’s another 2.5 day of leave accumulated. After that, it depends on how long your MOS school is. If it’s another 3 months or so of schooling, you may have enough leave to take again before you report to your first duty station. Most of the time your command will let you go on leave before your first duty station. You can go into a negative leave balance, if you have sick spouse or child or immediate family member . Once you hit your duty station, your command won’t let you go on leave until you have a positive leave balance, unless it’s a death in the family. Pro Tip: Find out the date when your MOS school actually starts. If you arrive there 3 weeks early like I did. You can be expected to help move furniture into new offices, and painting rocks in front of those new offices scarlet and gold, plus other general clean up duties. Also PTing, lots of PTing. Try to time your leave out until right about the time your MOS school starts. Little victories.

It depends upon your orders. If your graduate Boot Camp on 16 Oct and your school starts on 02 Nov then you can decide at that point on whether your want to go home for 2 weeks or go straight to your duty station. If home is your destination, fill out your leave paperwork and head home…If you want to get things started for yourself…..BE CREATIVE! I should have drove across country but my senses were limited then. Or, if you want to get used to your new digs and settle in, all you need to do is be to the airport on time. You report and then they will put you on rock painting duty until your school starts!

Most of your initial leave comes after recruit training. You usually get about 2 weeks off after that. So, you generally go straight to your first duty station after school unless it’s one of those uncommon ones that last almost a year or more. I’ve been out for a bit but I know people whose kids have recently earned the title. Hope that helps. Semper Fi and best of luck, devil pup.

Depends on how far away your station is and how you are traveling. If it is by air, you are usually allowed one day travel time. If it is by car, it is more like (my estimate - I don’t remember exactly) one day for every 300 miles. Also, it is common to permit the taking of leave at this time, but this is not automatic. Thiswill be specified n your assignment orders, and your reporting date will be specified.

Well, there is no ‘set’ amount of time allotted; you earn 30 days a year.. so you take 10 days after bootcamp… go to school, then take 10 more (that means that you will have to serve 8 months to have earned 20 days) as an example. 30 days is a lot of time… but it can be used up like a $100 bill; as soon as you break it, it is gone….

I think this varies depending on whether you go to SOI or MCT. I went to SOI, and the buses picked us up from graduation to take us over to Lejeune where we, officially, joined the fleet. There was no time off in between. I barely had time to shake hands with my instructors. I didn't get a “vacation” until we got a 96 for 4th of July.
That varies greatly, depending on your MOS, the needs of the unit you are going to, and how long your school was. A good rule of thumb is about 10 days.
Depends on where it is and how you are getting there, driving to a base in the same or new state or flying overseas in a foreign country
